I really don't like this.

The release process assumes all git revisions are under manifest control.

this feels like a temporary fix.  Especially with the rm commands
rm command is to clean the git repo when rebuilding the package, not for other purpose.

When I considered the change, I also asked myself this question. It should be a problem, if the revision is not in manifest, but finally I think no the issue at all. First of all, the meta-lat always points to master branch, as long as run repo sync, all meta data will be fetched. If someone just syncs up integ repository manually, it is not only a problem for this commit, but also for other commits, as long as the fix is combined by multi-commits in different repositories.

On the other hand, if someone wants to upgrade a package, he should confirm the new version package exists in upstream, and it also can be downloaded into local mirror by normal process. Likewise, if someone wants to upgrade the ostree, he should confirm the new revision exists in meta-lat upstream, and can be fetched to local tree by repo sync.
I 100% agree with you. Exactly, adding meta-lat into manifest is not a good solution. I am not sure why I didn't consider to use tarball at beginning. I will change it in this review.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: This sounds like a bug you've hit? Could you create an upstream bug and link to this in the commit message? Also, can you add a simple test to prevent us regressing?

IIRC this was done on purpose: the CommandFilter would allow /bin/echo and if you tried to run "echo" as root it would allow you (and execute /bin/echo). Now, I agree that a complete match (trying to run /bin/echo) should succeed.

One issue with your patch is that by comparing basenames, if you try to run /home/bob/bin/echo, the CommandFilter would just compare basenames (echo=echo) and allow it (and end up running /bin/echo).

So my recommendation would be to return True if basename(exec_path)==userargs[0] OR if exec_path == userargs[0] (but not is basename(exec_path)==basename(userargs[0]))
That totally makes sense. Thanks for the insights, I'll work on a revision.
I think the proposed patch works, see suggestions on how to make it more self-explaining/minimal

For clarity I would rename that variable "exact_path_matches" (exec_path is already used as an instance property so reusing same name would be confusing)
This becomes "base_path_matches or exact_path_matches" which is pretty self-explaining
I would also explicitly return False if no userargs are present, like the original function (to minimize the proposed change)
Not a big deal but I think it will be more readable to use ternary operator here.

Yes, as long as share_id is not provided, the scheduler hints become invalid e.g. line no 337

This lookup could be avoided if we set this into the request spec; have you considered it? We generally strive to keep the scheduler layer light on db lookups because these calls are fairly expensive in a large cloud

Ah i see, thanks for calling it out. This lookup must then happen in the _get_request_spec_dictionary method [1] in the API, like we do for shares and replicas: https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/a6177bcc0d533089eff509cc62d5313d4aaa44ba/manila/share/api.py#L550

manila/scheduler/filters/host.py.message:
I don't like that this is hardcoded. I would prefer to have control in the policy who can use this feature.
In my cloud installation I may want to give this permission to some elevated users, who are not overall admins.

One use-case I have in mind: running periodic tests that create a share on each host.
Handing out cloud admin permissions would be overkill, such a test user should be allowed to create shares on a pre-selected host, but not do other potential harmful stuff in my cloud installation.

I see it as an enhancement, which could go in a follow-up commit.

+1
This isn't really a hard-coded policy check; "context_is_policy" is customizable to any role. The "host" field itself is governed by this "context_is_admin" policy. perhaps we can add a new RBAC policy that controls the visibility of the "host" field as well as the use of "only_host"? 
Agree this  could come in a follow up change

manila/scheduler/host_manager.py.message: Would it be better if we add this filter as the first ?! The filter chain uses less compute resources when the most restrictive filter comes first. The "OnlyHostFilter" is the most restrictive one: only one host is acceptable. With this filter set first, all other filters will only check if the selected host can be used, removing all others one.
This makes sense and even other filters then need to not to iterate over all hosts.

- object ACLs: https://boto3.amazonaws.com/v1/documentation/api/latest/reference/services/s3.html#S3.Client.get_object_acl

swift/common/middleware/s3api/acl_handle.message:
I don't understand why this section works.

A few lines above, S3AclHandler inherits from BasicAclHandler. When request comes in, there's a bit of a shuffling and set_acl_handler(), but eventually handle_acl() is called. We don't have one, so the generic one works. It re-instantiates the handler for some reason, then does hasattr(). Presumably it's still S3AclHandler class. So, HEAD() is not present. Then it falls through to _handle_acl(), which invokes HEADs. So, the end result is not a GET as claimed by the changelog.

What am I missing?

deployment/glance/glance-api-container-p.message:
I don't believe this is accurate, because the chunk size pertains to all RBD objects. It's true the glance/cinder interop issue arose when cinder is cloning a glance image, but in cinder the same chunk size config option is used when creating a volume.

Looking at their respective code, glance defaults to 8M and cinder to 4M, so this patch will override cinder's default value and cinder will use 8M for all RBD volumes. I'm not suggesting this is a problem, just that this patch affects more than cloning operations.

Yes, when cloning an RBD image, previously the rbd lib would ignore the caller's chunk size (cinder's is 4M) in favor of the parent image's chunk size (glance's is 8M). The cinder patch you referenced in the commit message [1] fixed cinder so that it passes the parent's chunk size (which is 8M) regardless of cinder's configured chunk size (4M).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/804265

This patch would override both cinder's and glance's default chunk size. It won't directly impact glance, which already defaults to 8M, but it would override cinder's default value.

my understanding is that in previous versions the rbd library would ignore the value passed by the caller if the image chunk size did not match ... and use the image chunk size but as you pointed there might be other implications

Done!
This error will come back if CONFIG_CPUMASK_OFFSTACK is not set correct? So this is only a partial fix but based on the STX/WRCP kernel config this should not be a problem?

I would not consider this a partial fix, but I agree/admit that StarlingX is currently not affected because it disables MAXSMP and NR_CPUS is set to 256.

However, to answer your question, when CPUMASK_OFFSTACK is disabled, the upper limit for the maximum number of CPUs becomes 512.

Quoting from arch/x86/Kconfig:

```
config NR_CPUS_RANGE_END
        int
        depends on X86_64
        default 8192 if  SMP && CPUMASK_OFFSTACK
        default  512 if  SMP && !CPUMASK_OFFSTACK
        default    1 if !SMP
```

```
config NR_CPUS
        int "Maximum number of CPUs" if SMP && !MAXSMP
        range NR_CPUS_RANGE_BEGIN NR_CPUS_RANGE_END
        default NR_CPUS_DEFAULT 
        help
          This allows you to specify the maximum number of CPUs which this
          kernel will support.  If CPUMASK_OFFSTACK is enabled, the maximum
          supported value is 8192, otherwise the maximum value is 512.  The
          minimum value which makes sense is 2.
```

A cpumask consisting of 512 bits should correspond to 64 bytes on the stack.

I double-checked my statements in practical terms by disabling CPUMASK_OFFSTACK, setting NR_CPUS to 512, and FRAME_WARN=64 (just for testing):

```
$ grep -e MAXSMP= -e NR_CPUS= -e CPUMASK_OFFSTACK= -e FRAME_WARN= .config
CONFIG_NR_CPUS=512
CONFIG_FRAME_WARN=64

$ rm -f kernel/cpu.o kernel/.cpu.o.*; make -j4 kernel/cpu.o
  DESCEND  objtool
  CALL    scripts/atomic/check-atomics.sh
  CALL    scripts/checksyscalls.sh
  CC      kernel/cpu.o
kernel/cpu.c: In function 'kthread_setup':
kernel/cpu.c:2528:1: warning: the frame size of 72 bytes is larger than 64 bytes [-Wframe-larger-than=]
```

(The extra 8 bytes [i.e., 72 - 64] are likely due to the local variable 'int err' in the function.)

All this to say, I would consider this change to be a full/non-partial fix, within the kernel's limits on NR_CPUS.

I need to admit that StarlingX currently has the following configuration, which is not affected by the bug fixed by this patch:

```
# CONFIG_MAXSMP is not set
CONFIG_NR_CPUS=256
CONFIG_FRAME_WARN=2048
```
Thanks! I have reworded the commit message to clarify when the issue being fixed is applicable.

You don't have to include all of this information in the commit log but please add a line "When CPUMASK_OFFSTACK is disabled, the upper limit for the maximum number of CPUs becomes 512. So this does not return when CPUMASK_OFFSTACK".

I know you indirectly made this point by calling out specific kconfigs at play but adding this line doubles down on the point. Thanks.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: A few minor things to deal with.
Thanks for the updates. Looks good.

There are two mechanisms in play here, first using a local git repo or fork like you describe, but there is also the possibility to put a u-c file in /etc/openstack-deploy/.... as described in this releasenote https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/774523/10/releasenotes/notes/repo-server-uc-cache-74de275bfd82c998.yaml#14

There are a couple of reasons for this, the example in the reno is running master branch magnum on a stable release installation, and another use case would be like ours where we want to take the wallaby u-c file and simply adjust one entry. Putting a copy of just the u-c file in /etc/openstack-deploy allows it to be kept in version control along with the rest of the deployment config, if desired.

Tbh I'd say that we need to restore functionality of global-requirement-pins.txt 😞

Feels that for this purpose we'd need to move filtering from independent roles to python_venv_build and drop from u-c anything that is contained in venv_build_global_constraints

I had chosen not to document the option to drop a file in /etc/openstack_deploy as it still requires you to locate (and keep up to date) the upper constraints file from the git repo, so it seemed slightly less prone to error to perform a clone or maintain a fork rather than drop in a static file that might be forgotten about.

This maybe doesn't quite cover all cases

* The repo is cloned with git from the prepared zuul location retrieving a specific refspec
* The zuul location is set up with any patches as a result of depends-on
* When there is a depends on, is the zuul repo left with the branch moved forward to the applied patch, or is it "detached-head" state? i.e does master or stable/blah refer to the original branch head, or the depends-on state.

* openstack-ansible-plugins probably wants to be treated like a normal OSA role, installed from master on master branch and a pinned SHA on stable branches, while respecting depends-on in CI

* Upstream collections will only use released version numbers like x.y.z which we bump manually

* ansible-collections-openstack sits in between, were we want to use released versions but might need to depends-on in CI, particularly on master branch.

So:

Always use x.y.z version numbers for upstream roles

Where a zuul copy exists: take 'head of the current branch'? Does this work for depends-on?

In an upgrade job, do we always use the target (N-1) or (N) branch as the zuul state will be correct even for depends-on? Rememeber that with the source set to git+https:// ansible-galaxy does a git clone from the zuul copy.

fwiw, this is always present since Python 3.3 so we can probably deprecate this now [1]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/hmac.html#hmac.compare_digest

This seems like a bit of a hammer. This will prevent someone using this entire module if md5 isn't available. Could we instead do something like:

  try:
      ...
  except (TypeError, AttributeError):
      ...

i.e. extend the exception handlers so we'll simply handle the AttributeError that will be raised (I think. Can you check?) if the 'md5' function is not available in the first case, falling back to the legacy implementation. That'll simply mean a user can import this module. If they attempt to actually call the 'md5' function (as oposed to the 'constant_time_compare' function) then they will see an AttributeError.

Realistically, all calling code will need to add this check for 'md5' not supported. I don't think this is something we can handle unless we want to have an md5 function that returns something other than md5 😄

this looks an implementation detail, but OK. What you mean is that when restarting the service, this volume driver will verify the instance XMLs,right?

Let me try to explain what we see happening. If there is a better way to solve it, we'll be happy to do it. Let's say for the sake of simplicity that there is one VM running and attached to a host-mounted NVMe/TCP volume connected to the LightOS cluster. When the compute host goes down and comes back up, something on the host needs to reattach to that LightOS volume so that the device file will show up and the VM will reattach to it. So on nova libvirt volume driver startup we scan the list of instances on the compute host, figure out which should be connected to LightOS volumes (and to which LightOS volumes), and then connect to them so that the device files will show up. Then nova reattaches those device files to the appropriate instances. Makes sense or is there some flow we are missing that should have caused this to happen "automatically" (i.e, without our libvirt volume driver involvement?)

will the volume driver actuly do this.

the way this normally works is the compute manageer loops over all current isntnace on agent startup and ensueres they are provisioned correctly fi they are active.

if you have set the config option to resume guest on host reboot then the agent will start the instances that shoudl be running.

the voluem driver shoudl not need to query for any instances at start up as it will be invoked by the compute manage and libvirt drver for each instance that should be started.

os-brick and the volume driver shoudl not proactivaly be trying to mount anything on the host unles nova asks it too.

Our plan is to get both the cinder/os_brick and the nova parts merged for Yoga concurrently. We appreciate the feedback and are addressing it.

With regards to the volume attachment to the VM, I elaborated in the spec, but the short answer is that the host connects to the LightOS storage cluster via NVMe/TCP, leading to the creation of /dev/nvmeX device files, and those files are exposed to the VMs via the usual KVM/QEMU mechanisms (device hot plug). So unless I misunderstand what you mean by host mounted, it is host mounted.

LightOS supports many different types of containerized and virtualized environments in addition to openstack, including VMware, but the LightOS openstack support has only been tested with libvirt.

Masakari takes care of this situation in different way as of today. Instances with metadata "HA_Enabled=True" are evacuated first followed by the remaining ones from the failed compute host.

Do you think this helps to solve your problem?

Also, operator can decide whether to evacuate all instances or only instances which contain metadata "HA_Enabled=True" by configuring config option "evacuate_all_instances", By default it's value is set to True which means it will evacuate all instances from failed compute host.

specs/train/approved/evacuate-instances-.message:
Masakari takes care of this situation in different way as of today. Instances with metadata "HA_Enabled=True" are evacuated first followed by the remaining ones from the failed compute host.

Do you think this helps to solve your problem?

Also, operator can decide whether to evacuate all instances or only instances which contain metadata "HA_Enabled=True" by configuring config option "evacuate_all_instances", By default it's value is set to True which means it will evacuate all instances from failed compute host.

Metadata "HA_Enabled=True" and configuration "evacuate_all_instances" only determines which instances we expect to evacuate from failure host.How to do if not all expected instances can evacuate?

In my opinion, instances with "HA_Enabled=True" is prior than other normal instances. If we want to evacuate all instances, when configuration "evacuate_all_instances" is set 'True', it would be better to evacuate instances "HA_Enabled=True" firstly and other instances secondly, instead of unordered evacuations.

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/bios.py.message:
JFYI, there is reason why it is this way [1]. To be clear, as it was confusing before, it is still UTC NOW with timezone UTC+0, not system's local time or local time zone. This is necessary because of the way `timeutils.parse_isotime` works (see the link for examples). Not sure if there is another way around it, but didn't find similar cases in Ironic that needs the same.

If there is no definite plan how to update this, I rather remove this TODO or replace with explanation why can't use `timestamp_driver_internal_info`.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic/+/748696/comment/c4502f27_11144ca8/

thinking further, it actually could be fixed now, as the [1]^ was mainly about another lines that stay as they are.

Now ln 422-423 can be replace with 

  node.timestamp_driver_internal_info('factory_reset_time')

as 

  timeutils.utcnow(with_timezone=True)

can be replaced with 

 timeutils.utcnow().isoformat()

here (it's the same time, only different format/data type) and it will still work at line 226 where it's used.


Also found another instance when similar calculation is done in redfish firmware upgrade steps [2][3]

[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/1a03e613299c04c2bb6ea929ee94e776d3da2137/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/management.py#L831-L832
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/1a03e613299c04c2bb6ea929ee94e776d3da2137/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/management.py#L931-L933

The value is parsed with timeutils.parse_isotime, which correctly parses timeutils.utcnow().isoformat() and timeutils.utcnow(with_timezone=True)

So I agree with Aija that we can move to timestamp_driver_internal_info here now. I'll do a follow-up which does that.

OK these latencies threw me for a while. Because they happen on spawn we never actually use all 4. 

First async goes through because Bucket iter starts at 0.0. The async sleeps for 0.11 seconds. The second async is allowed out of the bucket iter because enough time has passed. It sleeps 0 seconds in fake_spawn. So the third async gets dropped because .10 seconds hasn't passed. The fourth is the same, because again the 0.10 seconds hasn't passed.

That's why we get 2 successes. if you then go look at the latencies left over we still got 2 left.

  # Put this at the end
  self.assertEqual(len(latencies), 2)

We already add the appropriate tag to the apache service resource so that httpd is started within the service block, which should be enough. We might be able to do this but in my past experience the string enforcement of apache stuff is likely to result in circular dependency and I'd prefer keeping the current implementation, which we already have in puppet-aodh.

Would it be better to just add Anchor['barbican::install::end'] -> Apache::Vhost<||> -> Anchor['barbican::config::end']  ?

I have a personal opinion on this that *might* be a point of discussion now...
We intend to add the deprecated warning to python-manilaclient at the end of the Yoga release, as we are closer than ever of feature parity.
So I was wondering if we should stop adding new functionalities to python-manilaclient. I can think of some pros and cons for this:
Pros:
- Enforce the adoption of OSC
- No need to write the same feature/modifications for both clients
Cons:
- Might cause disparity between the two clients

One question I think must be discussed with a broader audience is:
Is it a problem to start adding features to only one of the clients? Would be users complaining about this?
/me does not want to piss off anyone if this is the approach we choose.
Wdyt?

We discussed this at length at the PTG, and announced that new features would only debut in OSC. Since we're setting the stage for a future "manila" shell command that will look a lot like OSC, we need to actively deprecate the current "manila" command. Not having this feature in the manila shell command shouldn't hurt any existing users unless they want to add/manipulate metadata on resources where metadata isn't currently supported...

So, this spec says that the work items are in the manilaclient SDK (will not deprecated anytime soon) and manilaclient's OSC plugin ("openstack share ...") and not the manila shell..

"a subnet"? We are still currently supporting only one subnet to be attached to the share server

A share network was associated with neutron network and subnets even before the implementation of [1]... What changed since [1] is: A share server is associated with a share network subnet, which now withholds information of neutron. So in [1], the neutron fields were removed from share networks to share network subnets.
A suggestion to this paragraph would be:
Prior to the implementation of `[1]_`, the share network entity held information from Neutron networks and subnets, and Manila referred to its data when trying to dynamically allocate addresses.
Since the implementation of `[1]_`, the share network entity was modified to do not hold Neutron information, it was instead modified to span multiple share network subnets in different availability zones. Since then, share servers are created and associated with a single share network subnet, which contains neutron network and subnet information.

Actually, adding a new subnet might not be disruptive in some scenarios. Example:

Time 0: share S1 is created, causing the creation of share server SS1 in a subnet <SUB>, with IP X
Time 1: share S2 is created in the same share server SS1
Time 2: user A has the IP Y in the same subnet <SUB> connecting to share S1
Time 3: user B  cannot connect to share S2 because the subnet <SUB> has no more IPs to be assigned to him.
Time 4: add a new subnet <SUB_2> to the share server. 
Time 5: Ops, <SUB_2> has been wrongly configured. So, let's remove it and add the correct one.

The remove operation in the "time 5" won't cause any disruption, since the connected users are using the other subnet.

Therefore, the remove subnets MAY cause a disruption, depending on the setup, It's up to the user taking the risk. The point is, how should we mitigate misremove ?!

So, we could keep as the update security service, only implementing the update by "adding". The update remove part, if requested, will be addressed by a light spec later. This way, if the admin wants to remove a subnet, the share net must have no allocations on it (not in-use state).

Actually, there is a situation where having a check operation might be useful. Changing a share network may impact more then one backend at the same time and it would be more difficult to handle a scenario where you want to add a new IPv6 subnet and a backend A supports IPv6 but a backend B doesn't.

Focus will be IPv4 in a same broadcast domain for Yoga. A suggestion is to change to the following:

1. Multiple IPv4 subnets in a same network (Targeted to Yoga release)
2. Multiple IPv6 subnets in a same network
3. Multiple IPv4/IPv6 subnets in different networks

This is a driver implementation detail, and shouldn't be treat in manila.

If you take a look on security service update implementation, you will see a solution for that kind of issues.

In security service udpate, we have a check operation that validates with the driver if the operation is supported. You can use that check to validate if IPv4/Ipv6 operations are supported. The benefit is that we can check (like we do in migration) if a share network update is possible before triggering in share manager, and also give admins a tool to check if a share network update is valid. In the next releases you can improve your driver to support other protocol versions without changing nothing in core code.
The base implementation is already there (async check), you will be able to extend that to cover your scenario.

It was written by ganso, what I got from it:

by empty it means no share server related to that share network. So, the point here is: if the driver has no support
for updating share server allocations, it will only be a valid scheduler cadidate in case the multiple share network has no associated share server. Otherwise, the share netwok will lose the update support because of this new share server.

Example: I have two backends B1 and B2. B1 has support for multiple subnets, but no support for updating. B2 has support for both, updating and setup multiple subnets. I also have a multiple subnet share network called SN:

1. New share is created using SN. It is allocated to B2.
2. Another share is created using SN, the scheduler won't allow it to be created in the B1, because this would make
the entire share network without updating support. In another words, adding a share server without updating support to a share network with update support will lose the net update support.

The rate config may or may not be present in the hieradata for a particular interface based on:

https://opendev.org/starlingx/config/src/branch/master/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/interface.py#L1083

If it's not present, then for the sure the block will not be executed.  However, if it is present, the template to set the rate will be called.  This commit just enforces a dependency to ensure the driver is set before the particular rate setting is performed based on the PCI address.  It's more efficient to do it on a per-addr basis than as a dependency between the entire collection. (that is set the rate for VF 1 only after VF 1-64 drivers have been set, set the rate for VF 2 only after VF 1-64 drivers have been set, etc)

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Can use internal endpoint in the horizon configuration? Will it fix your issue?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Would be really great to be able to review/merge this patch as operators have legitimate requirements to run their control planes completely isolated from any external networks. Notably, devstack makes no effort to provide this isolation so situations which deployers face are never seen in openstack development/CI scenarios.

In this scenario it is not possible to configure horizon to use the internal endpoint, because with isolated networks the external keystone endpoints are correct for the client client browser, but horizon itself is communicating with keystone over the internal endpoint. This kind of split configuration is not possible with the current config options for horizon/websso.

In our case the fully isolated control plane behind internet facing external endpoints has provided us an excellent guard for our adjacent ELK stack against the recent log4j vulnerabilities which rely on being able to make outbound requests. I hope this provides context about why this patch is important to some operators.

Considering Last P.S already have two +2 and current P.S. only removing a space in release note.

tempest/scenario/test_network_qos_placem.message:
As this run proves[1] the interface removed from the API response before the actual detach finishes so we need to figure out a better waiter to assert that the allocation is removed.

[1]https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/a327cbb3287d4e6090baa598d75c4db6/log/compute1/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt#48177-48180

So the nova order of actions:
1) unplug the device from the VM
2) unbind the port in neutron
3) deallocate resources

The os-interfaces API list plugged interfaces based on the list of ports bound to the instance. So the wait_for_interface_detach could return at 2) but this assert can still see the allocated resources in placement if it run before 3) finishes.

We need to wait for the os-instance-actions to list that the detach is finished before we can assert. That action is only recorded after 3).

=> Done
